occsphere.head: Occupation, Sphere of Activity
occsphere.p: Henry Pitney Van Dusen was educated at The University of Princeton, New College, Edinburgh, and at Union Theological Seminary, New York. He returned to Edinburgh as a postgraduate student. His challenge of the literal interpretation of the virgin birth became an obstacle to ordination but this was overcome with the support of the likes of John Foster Dulles.

Teaching initially at various American colleges, he returned to take up a post at Union Theological Seminary in 1926. An international figure, he was prominent in founding the World Council of Churches.

relships.head: Relationships
relships.p: Henry Pitney Van Dusen married Elizabeth Coghill Bartholomew, daughter of Scottish cartographer John George Bartholomew

honqual.head: Honours, Qualifications and Appointments
honqual.p: 1924: B.D., Union Theological Seminary, New York
1936: appointed Roosevelt Professor of Systematic Theology, Union Theological Seminary, New York
1945: appointed President, Union Theological Seminary, New York
